title: SB 1073
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 17052 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to allow an earned income tax credit against the "net tax" for taxable years starting January 1, 2015. The credit amount is determined based on Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code, adjusted by a factor for the taxable year. The earned income tax credit adjustment factor for taxable years starting January 1, 2015, is 0 percent unless specified otherwise in the annual Budget Act. The credit is only applicable when resources are allocated in the Budget Act for oversight and auditing by the Franchise Tax Board. The earned income tax credit is only operational when resources are allocated in the Budget Act for oversight and auditing by the Franchise Tax Board. The credit percentage and phaseout percentage vary based on the number of qualifying children. The earned income tax credit varies based on the number of qualifying children, with different credit and phaseout percentages for each scenario. Additionally, the earned income amount and phaseout amount are determined based on the number of qualifying children for eligible individuals. Joint returns are not subject to certain provisions of the Internal Revenue Code related to the earned income tax credit. The earned income tax credit amounts vary based on the number of qualifying children, with specific earned income and phaseout amounts for each scenario. Certain provisions of the Internal Revenue Code related to joint returns and qualifying children are modified. The earned income tax credit amounts vary based on the number of qualifying children, with specific earned income and phaseout amounts for each scenario. Certain provisions of the Internal Revenue Code related to joint returns and qualifying children are modified, including withholding requirements under the Unemployment Insurance Code. Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code is modified to include withholding requirements under the Unemployment Insurance Code. The earned income tax credit amount is increased to $3,400. Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code is modified to include withholding requirements under the Unemployment Insurance Code. Section 32(c)(2)(A)(ii) is exempted, section 32(c)(3)(C) is modified to refer to "this state," and section 32(i)(1) is changed to $3,400. Inflation adjustments for taxable years starting January 1, 2016, will be recomputed annually. In lieu of Section 32(j) of the Internal Revenue Code, for taxable years starting on or after January 1, 2016, specified amounts will be recomputed annually. Any excess credit under this section will be applied to other amounts due, with the remaining balance refunded to the taxpayer from the Tax Relief and Refund Account. If the credit exceeds tax liability, the excess will be credited against other amounts due, with the remaining balance refunded to the taxpayer from the Tax Relief and Refund Account. The Franchise Tax Board may establish rules to implement this section. The Franchise Tax Board can create rules for this section, exempt from certain government code regulations. Refunds under this section are treated like federal earned income refunds for benefit eligibility under the Welfare and Institutions Code. Refunds under this section will be treated like federal earned income refunds for benefit eligibility under the Welfare and Institutions Code. The Franchise Tax Board is exempt from specific government code regulations for implementing the credit allowed for the 2015 taxable year. The Franchise Tax Board must comply with various reporting requirements for the implementation of the credit allowed for the 2015 taxable year, as outlined in State Administrative Manual Sections, Statewide Information Management Manual, the 2015 Budget Act, and the Public Contract Code. The scope, costs, and schedule changes related to this credit must be included in the next Special Project Report for the Enterprise Data to Revenue Project. The Franchise Tax Board must incorporate the scope, costs, and schedule changes of the California Earned Income Tax Credit in its next Special Project Report. The purpose of the credit is to reduce poverty among California's working families and individuals, with annual reports required to measure its effectiveness. The California Earned Income Tax Credit aims to reduce poverty among working families and individuals. The Franchise Tax Board must annually report on the number of tax returns claiming the credit, individuals represented, average credit amount, and distribution of credits by dependents and income ranges. The report on the California Earned Income Tax Credit includes the distribution of credits by number of dependents and income ranges, as well as estimates of families lifted out of deep poverty by the credit and federal tax credit. The Franchise Tax Board will provide a written report to various Senate and Assembly committees regarding the California Earned Income Tax Credit. The tax credit will apply to taxable years starting from January 1, 2016.
